awd_titl_txt: Nonlinear Fluid and Kinetic Effects in Nonneutral Plasmas
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a program of experiments, theory, and simulations on a range of fundamental nonlinear processes in plasmas. The studies will focus on problems for which precise experimental tests of theory can be obtained. Experiments will be performed on non-neutral plasmas, plasmas that contain a mixture of free electrons, ions, and uncharged species, using an electron trap and an ion trap with a broad range of operating regimes and diagnostics. The simplicity of these systems allows a depth of understanding and a precision of comparison between theory and experiment that is rarely possible otherwise. The award will support training of a graduate student, and results of the research will have broader applications to natural and engineered plasma systems, including space plasmas and fusion plasmas for power generation.

The project is an integrated study of nonlinear plasma processes including wave-wave interactions; particle, heat, and momentum transport caused by applied electric and magnetic field perturbations; and effects associated with nonlinear particle trapping in both waves and applied fields.  Ongoing experiments have observed nonlinear wave instabilities with features that are consistent with a new kinetic particle theory of nonlinear particle detrapping and retrapping in the wave troughs. These experiments, along with accompanying theory and simulations, will be extended in order to consider this trapped particle mechanism in the context of other waves, including nonneutral ion acoustic waves in mixed H-electron plasmas, and electron acoustic waves. New experiments on negative ion-electron nonneutral plasmas will also be pursued, making connections to nonlinear processes of importance in quasi-neutral plasmas and in plasmas used in anti-hydrogen production. A major focus will be on the interplay between effects of convective fluid nonlinearity versus kinetic trapped particle nonlinearity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF award supported a broad range of theory and experimental work on the basic physics of magnetically-confined plasmas. The experiments used nonneutral plasmas (plasma consisting of one or more charge species, all with the same sign of charge) confined in the static electric and magnetic fields of a cylindrical Penning trap. Such plasmas can be confined for long periods of time (minutes to days). The research focused on detailed studies of small and large amplitude plasma waves and instabilities, cross-magnetic field transport, and plasma `kinetic’ effects such as the formation and nonlinear evolution of flattened regions and holes in the phase space particle distribution of the plasma. Such  regions are often associated with the excitation of large amplitude waves, and can result in instabilities due to the deviation from a thermal Maxwellian particle distribution.   

For example, our collaboration with the University of Calabria is exploring a nonlinear kinetic instability in electron acoustic waves (EAWs).  These waves are observed in space plasmas as well as in laboratory pure electron plasmas. A parametric instability in these waves, driven by particles that are weakly trapped on the edges of phase space holes associated with the wave,  has been identified in computer simulation. A theory of the instability is currently under development.

 

In the area of linear and nonlinear wave analysis, Dubin developed a theory to describe general plasma perturbations by decomposing any such perturbation into a sum of the linear waves of the plasma system, with wave amplitudes determined by an integral over the perturbation (an `inner product’) that is related to the energy of the waves (or more generally, to any constant of the wave motion).  Such a description is helpful in understanding how energy flows from wave to wave as perturbations evolve in time, and was used by Dubin to describe several low order nonlinear wave instabilities, in which large amplitude waves decay in amplitude by transferring their energy to other waves via nonlinear resonances. The theory of these nonlinear instabilities was then compared to experiments measuring the decay rates of the large amplitude waves, testing the instability theory.

For example, using the above analysis method Dubin developed a new theory of nonlinear decay instability that can occur on the edge of a fluid vortex (such as a hurricane)  or  in an electron plasma. In this process, a diocotron mode (a distortion in the shape of the vortex away from cicularity) decays into a diocotron mode with lower azimuthal mode number (i.e. a longer wavelength distortion), and a beat wave that oscillates at the frequency difference of the two diocotron modes. We have compared the theory to experiments performed in our group on the UCSD CamV device, finding agreement with the new theory.

In addition to these studies, a collaboration with Prof. Matt Stoneking and German graduate student Patrick Steinbrunner has led to improved understanding of the equilibrium and dynamics of electron plasmas confined in a levitated dipole configuration, currently being studied experimentally. Eventually the electron plasmas will be mixed with positron plasmas in order to study neutral or near-neutral antimatter plasma dynamics.

An important goal of the grant involves supporting the training of Ph.D. students. Tom O'Neil and Dan Dubin have both acted as research advisors for German Ph.D. student Patrick Steinbrunner. This collaboration has resulted in a published paper in J. Plas. Phys. and APS-DPP posters, as well as ongoing work on a paper on stability properties of the levitated dipole system. 

In addition, UCSD graduate student Jacob Saret wrote a Masters thesis on experimental work performed on the EV Penning trap and was recently granted a Masters degree based on this work. The core of the work involved the measurement of the nonlinear three-wave decay process of electron acoustic waves excited on a pure elecron plasma column.

This research remains closely tied to other disciplines, such as conventional fluids dynamics, atomic physics, charged particle beams, space plasma physics, and anti-matter containment.  The grant helped fund a continuing fruitful synergism with the Surko group in the areas of positron trapping and 2D fluid dynamics, as well as a collaboration with the NIST ion storage group at Boulder CO.
